statement.tex: %text Find the equation of the plane passing through the points $(3,4,1)$ and $(0,1,0)$ and parallel to the line $\dfrac{x+3}{2}=\dfrac{y-3}{7}=\dfrac{z+2}{5}$ %

step.context: %text If A, B and C are the direction ratios of a plane that passes through $(3,4,1)$ and $(0,1,0)$ is the following correct? %
step.reason: %text The equation of a plane having direction ratios A, B and C, which contains point $(x_1, y_1, z_1)$, is given by, % \qquad A(x-x_1)+B(y-y_1)+C(z-z_1)=0 \\ %text Therefore for the given plane which contains $(3,4,1)$ the equations is, % \qquad A(x-3)+B(y-4)+C(z-1)=0 \\ %text Further, $(0,1,0)$ satisfies this equation therefore, % \begin{align} &A(0-3)+B(1-4)+C(0-1)=0 \\ \implies & 3A+3B+C=0 \end{align}

step.context: %text If a plane with direction ratios A, B and C is parallel to line $\dfrac{x+3}{2}=\dfrac{y-3}{7}=\dfrac{z+2}{5}$, is the following true? %
step.reason: %text If a plane with direction ratios $a_1$, $b_1$, $c_1$ contains or is parallel to a line with direaction ratios $a_2$, $b_2$, $c_2$, the normal of the plane is perpendicular to the said line. Therefore they represent vectors whose dot-product is zero. Hence, % \qquad a_1a_2+b_1b_2+c_1c_2=0 \\ %text In the given problem the direction ratios of $\dfrac{x+3}{2}=\dfrac{y-3}{7}=\dfrac{z+2}{5}$ are $2$, $7$ and $5$, % \qquad \therefore 2A+7B+5C=0

step.context: %text If $A(x-3)+B(y-4)+C(z-1)=0$ and % \qquad \begin{align} & 3A+3B+C=0 \\ & 2A+7B+5C=0 \end{align} \\ %text what is the final equation of the plane? %
step.reason:
\qquad\begin{align} & 3A+3B+C=0 \\ & 2A+7B+5C=0 \end{align} \\ %text Using the above equations and expressing A and B in terms of C we get, % \qquad {\bf A:B:C=8:-13:15} \\ %text
Substituting A. B and C as $8k$, $-13k$ and $15k$ in $A(x-3)+B(y-4)+C(z-1)=0$, % \begin{align} & 8k(x-3)-13k(y-4)+15k(z-1)=0 \\ \implies & 8x-24-13y+52+15z-15=0 \\ \implies & {\bf 8x-13y+15z+13=0} \end{align}
